Legal_Issue: Whether the appellant meets the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Appellant accumulated only 357 days of residence in Canada within the four years preceding the application
Court_Ruling: Appellant does not meet the statutory residency requirement
Defendant_Behavior: Studied abroad, resulting in insufficient physical presence in Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to meet minimum residency requirement for citizenship
Legal_Standard: Three years (1,095 days) of physical residence in Canada within the four years prior to application
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence in Canada, purpose of 'Canadianization'
Evidence_Used: Record of days of residence in Canada
Application_Basis: Requirement of physical residence for citizenship eligibility
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and timing of the appellant's presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicant must have at least 1,095 days of physical residence in Canada in the four years before application
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant must reapply after fulfilling residency requirement
Cause_Description: Appellant applied for Canadian citizenship but failed to meet the residency requirement due to time spent studying abroad
Evidence_Handling: Residence duration calculated based on official records
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ 357 days vs. required 1,095 days
Evidence_Assessment: Quantitative evaluation of days physically present in Canada
Decision_Rationale: Statutory requirement not met; absence undermines 'Canadianization' objective
Legal_Standard_Applied: Literal and purposive interpretation of s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
